alert.note: Alert for Kennebec (Maine) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 24 at 11:38AM EST until December 25 at 12:20PM EST by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in New Hampshire and Maine... Pemigewasset River At Plymouth affecting Grafton and Belknap Counties. Kennebec River At Skowhegan affecting Somerset and Kennebec Counties. Suncook River At North Chichester affecting Merrimack and Belknap Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Maine... Kennebec River at Hallowell affecting Sagadahoc and Kennebec Counties. Kennebec River At Augusta affecting Kennebec County. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Maine and New Hampshire... Saco River At Conway affecting Carroll, Oxford, and Cumberland Counties. Piscataquog River NEAR Goffstown affecting Hillsborough County. Kennebec River At North Sidney affecting Kennebec County. Warner River At Davisville affecting Merrimack County. For the Kennebec River...including Skowhegan, North Sidney, Augusta, Hallowell...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Suncook River...including North Chichester...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Kennebec River at Augusta. * WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Water begins to flood parking lots on Front Street in Augusta. At 14.0 feet, Water reaches 2 feet deep in parking lots on Front Street in Augusta. At 15.0 feet, Much of the parking lot on Front Steet in Augusta floods. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:18 AM EST Saturday the stage was 11.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate above flood stage with a maximum value of 13.5 feet late this afternoon. It will fall below flood stage tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 14.1 feet on 12/02/2020. &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/gray.
